data.title: Best high school football players this century, ranked
data.meta_description: These are the top five-star recruits since 2000
data.text:
These are the top five-star recruits since 2000

Who are the best high-school football players to emerge on the college recruiting scene this century? And where do the likes of Arch Manning and Trevor Lawrence rank? Here's a rundown of the top five-star-rated recruits since 2000; 54 players in all are ranked. Our updated list is based on247Sports’ All-Time Football Players recruiting rankings, as well as the247Sports Composite ratings for the recruiting classes of2022 and2023.

Our rundown here is so packed with elites that you’ll find a tie at the No. 1 spot, with the seven players rated as perfect 1.0000s by the 247 Composite formula. (Where there were ties, we’ve listed players alphabetically.) The “lowest” score you’ll find here is 0.9988.

Our list runs from old school to new school. Three players hail from the recruiting Class of 2000; three hail from theClass of 2023. Overall, the player scores are current as of publication date.

Some of the standouts on this list went on to star for colleges such as Alabama,Clemson,USC andTexas. Some saw their skills translate to success in the NFL. And some saw their careers top out at high school. But once upon a time, they wereall greats.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9988

This 6-foot-2, 225-pound linebacker from Miami Carol City Senior High School in Miami Gardens, Florida, drew comparisons to Lawrence Taylor. But "college football's first celebrity recruit," as Bleacher Report labeled this standout from the 2004 recruiting class, was not to be a gridiron legend for long. He bounced from Miami, to junior college, to Louisville (where he was dismissed from the team) to a prison stint in Kentucky.

Of late, Williams was back in South Florida, working as a coach and trainer -- and sharing lessons learned along the way. "...[I]t was so crazy where I felt like I made it before I made it,” Williams told Miami's WSVN in 2021. "...[But] this my calling because I felt so good giving back.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9988

This standout defensive end from Florida's IMG Academy was the overall No. 3-rated player in the 2018 recruiting class. He took his college game to Clemson.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9988

Before his eight-season-long NFL career, and before his Rose Bowl-winning run with USC, Mark Sanchez was the pride of Mission Viejo, California. He was the top-rated QB and the No. 3-rated talent overall in the 2005 recruiting class.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9988

Charles Rogers had it all. At Michigan's Saginaw High, he was the top-rated receiver in the 2000 recruiting class. At Michigan State, he was a unanimous All-American. At the 2003 NFL Draft, he was the No. 2 overall pick of the Detroit Lions. But then the music stopped. Injuries and personal troubles doomed him to just 15 pro games over three seasons. Rogers died in 2019 at the age of 38. "Everyone around Saginaw loved Charles Rogers … everyone,” a former Saginaw High teammate told MLive.com.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9988

Seantrel Henderson was an offensive tackle out of Cretin-Derham Hall in Minnesota. USA Today's one-time high-school Offensive Player of the Year was the No. 2-rated talent of the 2010 recruiting class. He starred in college for Miami, and was a seventh-round pick in the 2014 NFL Draft.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9988

Cam Newton and Tyrod Taylor were both quarterbacks in the 2007 recruiting class, but they weren't Jimmy Clausen. Per scouts, Clausen, out of Oaks Christian School in Westlake Village, California, was the QB. In 2006, Clausen rolled up in a white Hummer limo to announce he was going to take his talents to Notre Dame. A second-round pick of the 2010 NFL Draft, Clausen's pro career consisted of 22 games over four seasons.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9989

This defensive end from Eastside Catholic in Sammamish, Washington, was the No. 3 talent in the 2021 recruiting class. 247Sports' Brandon Huffman called J.T. Tuimoloau "[p]owerful, athletic and nimble." Tuimoloau committed to Ohio State, and appeared in all 13 games for the Buckeyes in 2021.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9989

The 2017 247Sports Composite National Player of the Year, Jaelen Phillips impressed at Redlands East Valley in Redlands, California. The defensive end set off for UCLA, but transferred to Miami after two seasons.

In the 2021 NFL Draft, Phillips was a first-round pick for the Miami Dolphins.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9989

This five-star offensive tackle out of Florida's IMG Academy was part of Alabama's historically great 2021 recruiting class. 247Sports ranked JC Latham as Alabama's 12th-most important player heading into the 2022 college football season.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9990

In 2002, St. Bonaventure High's Whitney Lewis bested the likes of Helix High's Reggie Bush to win the Los Angeles Times' Glenn Davis Award, presented annually to the top high-school football player in Southern California. The wide receiver headed off to USC, but only played sparingly for the Trojans before transferring to Northern Iowa.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9990

This speedster and track star quite nearly ran to the top of 2006's recruiting class via Landstown High School in Virginia Beach, Virginia. Championships with the Florida Gators and Seattle Seahawks ensued.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9991

The son of former South Carolina linebacker Derrick Little, the 6-foot-6 Greg Little opted for Ole Miss after a run as the 2016 recruiting class' best offensive lineman. The Carolina Panthers selected the younger Little in the second round of the 2019 NFL Draft.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9991

A high-school All-American out of Apopka High in Apopka, Florida, this powerful run-blocker was the overall No. 2-rated talent in the 2015 recruiting class. He went on to play at Florida, and in the XFL.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9992

In the 2005 recruiting class, DeSean Jackson was a Top 25-rated talent, but Patrick Turner out of Goodpasture Christian School, in Madison, Tennessee was the top-rated receiver and the overall No. 2-ranked player. Turner went on to USC, and a 24-game career in the NFL.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9992

This explosive defensive tackle from Westover Comprehensive High in Albany, Georgia, was the top-rated player in the 2015 recruiting class. He went on to a college career with Georgia. Undrafted by the NFL, Thompson caught on with the Canadian Football League.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9992

In the star-packed recruiting class of 2014, this future first-round NFL draft pick and Heisman Trophy finalist from New Jersey's Paramus Catholic High was the overall No. 3-rated player. Peppers joined the New York Giants in 2019.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9992

This offensive tackle from Plainfield High in New Jersey was the top-rated player of the 2005 recruiting class. Monroe went on to play for Virginia, and log seven seasons in the NFL for the Jacksonville Jaguars and Baltimore Ravens. Monroe was the eighth overall pick of the 2009 NFL Draft.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9992

Cormani McClain is a nearly 6-foot-2 cornerback out of Florida's Lakeland High. He's the first member of the 2023 recruiting class on this list -- that pool's No. 3-ranked overall talent, and the top-rated defensive player. As of publication, McClain had not committed to a college. The 247Sports scouting report by Andrew Ivins called McClain a "new-age cornerback prospect that almost looks like he was made in some type of create-a-player mode."

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9992

This 6-foot-5, defensive tackle drew attention at Wake Forest High in Wake Forest, North Carolina, for his size and strength. He was the overall No. 2-rated player of the 2016 recruiting class. After a standout career with the Clemson Tigers, Lawrence was selected by the New York Giants in the first round of the 2019 NFL Draft.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9992

Kevin Jones was an elite running back from Cardinal O'Hara in Springfield, Pennsylvania, who was judged the top talent of the 2001 recruiting class. Jones went on to play at Virginia Tech, and enjoy a career in the NFL with the Chicago Bears and Detroit Lions.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9992

The Pro Bowl wide receiver first turned heads at Foley High in Foley, Alabama. The standout was the overall No. 3-rated player from the 2008 recruiting class. Jones enjoyed a three-year college career with Alabama before becoming the sixth overall pick of the 2011 NFL Draft. Through his first 11 NFL seasons, primarily spent with the Atlanta Falcons, Jones was named to the Pro Bowl seven times.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9992

At Cleveland's Glenville High, the future NFL wide receiver and Ohio State Buckeyes star was "a terror as a defensive back," praised Parade, which named Ginn to its high-school All-American team. At Glenville, the standout from the recruiting class of 2004 played for his father, coach Ted Ginn Sr.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9992

This running back from the recruiting class of 2009 had a bumpy start to his collegiate career: He verbally committed to Miami before switching to Tennessee, and later transferring to Kansas State. But he had a smooth takeoff from East High in Wichita, Kansas, where he was a high-school All-American. He went on to play four seasons in the NFL.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9992

In the 2002 recruiting class, only Vince Young was more highly regarded than Lorenzo Booker from St. Bonaventure in Ventura, California. Booker went on to play running back at Florida State. He bounced around the pros, with stops along the way with the Chicago Bears and the United Football League's Hartford Colonials.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9993

The future Pro Ball defensive end was the No. 2-rated talent in the 2014 recruiting class out of Martin High in Arlington, Texas. Myles Garrett went on to Texas A&M. He was the overall No. 1 pick of the 2017 NFL Draft for the Cleveland Browns.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9993

The 6-foot-5 Korey Foreman was the No. 2-rated talent in the 2021 recruiting class. The defensive end out of Centennial High in Corona, California, went on to play for USC, where he recorded 2.5 sacks for the Trojans in his freshman year. 247Sports' Charles Power judged that Foreman has the potential "to develop into a first round NFL Draft pick."

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9993

Matt Barkley is seen here as a 9th-grader, back when he was attracting attention as a freshman starter for Mater Dei in Santa Ana, California. The No. 1-ranked talent from the 2009 recruiting class, Barkley went onto become a true-freshman starter for USC. He was a fourth-round selection in the 2012 NFL Draft.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9994

Bryce Young was the No. 2-ranked talent in the 2020 recruiting class out of the quarterback factory that is Mater Dei in Santa Ana, California. For college, the dual-style QB with the "live arm" left the West Coast for Alabama. He won the 2021 Heisman Trophy in his sophomore year with the Crimson Tide, and was projected to be a top pick of the 2023 NFL Draft.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9994

The high-school All-American linebacker out of Florida's IMG Academy was the top-rated player in the 2019 recruiting class. At Georgia, Smith recorded 9.5 sacks in his first three seasons for the Bulldogs. He was projected to be a potential first-round pick of the 2023 NFL Draft.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9994

The main attraction of the 2006 recruiting class, Andre Smith starred at offensive tackle at Huffman High in Birmingham, Alabama, before moving onto the Alabama Crimson Tide -- and the Outland Trophy. The first-round pick of the 2009 NFL Draft, Smith started his pro career with the Cincinnati Bengals.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9994

The No. 2-ranked talent in the 2023 recruiting class is a quarterback product of Orange County, California's Los Alamitos High. Malachi Nelson committed to USC -- and head coach Lincoln Riley. The 247Sports scouting report by Gabe Brooks called Nelson "[p]erhaps the most natural thrower in an excellent 2023 QB group."

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9994

Cyrus Kouandjio emerged from DeMatha Catholic in Hyattsville, Maryland. The 6-foot-7 tackle was the No. 2-ranked overall talent in the 2011 recruiting class, and the top-rated offensive tackle. He played for three years at Alabama. The second-round pick of the 2014 NFL Draft last played in the league in 2018.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9995

The son of a former Dallas Cowboys cornerback, Mario Edwards Jr. was touted as the top player from Texas in the 2012 recruiting class. He showed his promise at Ryan High in Denton, Texas. before moving onto Florida State, and eventually the NFL.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9995

The No. 1-ranked player in the 2020 recruiting class, Bryan Bresee is a 6-foot-5 defensive tackle of out of Damascus High in Damascus, Maryland. He moved onto Clemson in 2020, and was considered a potential first-round pick of the 2023 NFL Draft.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9996

Peterson was the top-rated talent in the 2004 recruiting class. The running back out of Palestine High in Palestine, Texas, went on to attend Oklahoma. As a Sooners freshman, he was the runner-up in 2004 Heisman Trophy voting.

Peterson was the seventh overall pick of the 2007 NFL Draft. He was named NFL MVP in 2012.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9996

You have to be pretty good to be ranked higher than Myles Garrett, and Leonard Fournette was -- and is -- pretty good. The top-rated talent of the 2014 recruiting class over Garrett, Fournette starred at running back for St. Augustine in New Orleans, before moving onto LSU and the NFL.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9997

The veteran NFL wide receiver and Ohio State quarterback, Terrelle Pryor was the No. 2-rated player in the 2008 recruiting class. Back in the day, Pryor was a dual-threat QB for Jeannette High in Jeannette, Pennsylvania.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9997

Walter Nolen was the No. 2-rated talent in the 2022 recruiting class. The 6-foot-4 defensive tackle out of Tennessee's St. Benedict at Auburndale committed to Texas A&M. The 247Sports scouting report by Barton Simmons judged Nolen was "poised to develop into an early round NFL Draft pick."

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9997

Really big things were expected of Joe McKnight, the top star of the 2007 recruiting class. The running back from New Orleans' John Curtis High committed to USC, where he was supposed to be the next Reggie Bush. After running afoul of NCAA rules, not unlike Bush, McKnight entered the 2010 NFL Draft. The fourth-round pick moved around from the NFL to the Canadian Football League. He was under contract to the CFL when he was fatally shot in Louisiana in a 2016 road-rage case. McKnight was 28.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9997

The defensive end out of Bamberg-Ehrhardt High in Bamberg, South Carolina, was the No. 1-ranked player in the 2008 recruiting class. He went on to play at Clemson, and was a second-round pick of the 2011 NFL Draft. After a run with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, he ended his playing career with the Canadian Football League's Edmonton Eskimos.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9998

The top-rated talent of the 2000 recruiting class, tied with Brock Berlin, linebacker D.J. Williams went on to rack up honors at Miami, and carve out a long career in the NFL. Williams was a first-round pick of the 2004 NFL Draft. He played for the Denver Broncos and Chicago Bears.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9998

Upon entering college, this Class of 2012 receiver went from being a true freshman playmaker for Missouri to being dismissed from the team following a drug-related arrest. Though he never played in a game at his next school, Oklahoma, Green-Beckham was a second-round selection of the 2015 NFL Draft.

Off-the-field troubles persisted. To date, his pro career has consisted of 12 NFL starts over two years, from 2015-2016.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9998

Justin Fields was the second-rated talent in the 2018 recruiting class out of Harrison High in Kennesaw, Georgia. The quarterback played in 12 games for the Georgia Bulldogs before passing for more than 5,300 yards in two seasons for the Ohio State Buckeyes. The Chicago Bears selected him with the 11th overall pick of the 2021 NFL Draft.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9998

The other top-rated talent of the 2000 recruiting class, Brock Berlin was a pro-style quarterback out of Evangel Christian Academy in Shreveport, Louisiana. In college, he played for Florida and Miami. After going undrafted, he struggled to catch on in the NFL, playing in just two games in two years.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9999

A defensive end out of Rancho Verde High in Moreno Valley, California, Ronald Powell was the overall top-rated talent of the 2010 recruiting class. Going forward, injuries plagued him at Florida, and he went in the fifth round of the 2014 NFL Draft. His pro career consisted of two tackles.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9999

Back at Cartersville High in Cartersville, Georgia, Trevor Lawrence was the No. 1-rated talent in the 2018 recruiting class. He edged out Justin Fields for the honor. As a freshman at Clemson, Lawrence quarterbacked the school to a national championship. He was the overall No. 1 pick of the 2021 NFL Draft for the Jacksonville Jaguars.

247Sports Composite Rating: 0.9999

The No. 1-ranked player in the 2022 recruiting class, Travis Hunter is a cornerback out of Collins Hill High in Suwanee, Georgia, who upended expectations when he decommitted from Florida State, and signed with Jackson State. The flip was a coup for the HBCU -- and head coach Deion Sanders.

"It’s a moment many consider to be the most shocking in recruiting history...," 247Sports' Chris Hummer wrote.

247Sports Composite Rating: 1.0000

And here we are: Vince Young is the first of six players on our list at No. 1. Like his fellow top-rated talents, Young, out of Madison High in Madison, Texas, notched a perfect recruiting score. A member of the 2002 recruiting class, Young went onto glory at Texas; he is one of our 50 best college football players of all time. A first-round pick of the 2006 NFL Draft, Young notched two Pro Bowl seasons for the Tennessee Titans.

247Sports Composite Rating: 1.0000

No one was more highly coveted in the 2003 recruiting class than Ernie Sims out of North Florida Christian in Tallahassee, Florida. The linebacker went on to play at Florida State, and become a first-round pick of the 2006 NFL Draft. He logged eight pro seasons, including two with the Dallas Cowboys.

247Sports Composite Rating: 1.0000

The defensive end from Grayson High in Loganville, Georgia, was considered the ultimate player of the 2013 recruiting class. The acclaim continued at Ole Miss, and right on through to the 2016 NFL Draft, where he was a first-round pick. The pro career has been bumpier, though. He last played in an NFL game in 2019.

247Sports Composite Rating: 1.0000

The 6-foot-5 defensive tackle from Paramus Catholic in Paramus, New Jersey, was rated as the virtually perfect player of the 2016 recruiting class. He went on to become a standout at Michigan, and was the twelfth overall pick of the 2019 NFL Draft.

247Sports Composite Rating: 1.0000

Quinn Ewers is a 6-foot-3 pro-style quarterback out of Texas' Carroll Senior High, aka Southlake Carroll. Once the No. 1-rated talent in the 2022 recruiting class, Ewers reclassed to enroll at Ohio State -- and promptly became the No. 1-rated talent in the 2021 group.

At Ohio State, Ewers took two snaps for the Buckeyes in 2021 (and inked name, image and likeness deals) before entering the transfer portal, and taking his talents to Texas, where Arch Manning presumably will join him in 2023.

247Sports Composite Rating: 1.0000

Even among No. 1s, Jadaveon Clowney is in a class of his own. The defensive end out of South Pointe High in Rock Hill, South Carolina, was the top-rated talent of the 2011 recruiting class. After racking up honors at South Carolina, Clowney became the overall No. 1 pick of the 2014 NFL Draft. (He, Myles Garrett and Trevor Lawrence are the only No. 1 overall draft picks on this list.) Clowney notched three Pro Bowl seasons with the Houston Texans.
